section.title: Overview
section.p: NCC collects measurements for the following system and operating system metrics:

row.entry: The last time that the system was started (in Unix time).
Number of processes blocked waiting for I/O to complete
Number of processes in runnable state
Number of kilobytes the system has paged in from disk
Number of kilobytes the system has paged out to disk

entry.p: The following are examples in XML format:
entry.codeblock: <measType p="1">node_load1</measType> <measType p="2">node_load5</measType> <measType p="3">node_load15</measType> <measValue measObjLdn="platform=1, host=ME2-comsvc-2"> <r p="1">0.07250000000000002</r> <r p="2">0.13249999999999995</r> <r p="3">0.10350000000000004</r> </measValue>

<measType p="1">node_vmstat_pgpgin</measType> <measType p="2">node_vmstat_pgpgout</measType> <measValue measObjLdn="platform=1, host=ME2-comsvc-2"> <r p="1">571013</r> <r p="2">1822514</r> </measValue>

note.p: The actual values are taken by Prometheus as node_cpu_seconds_total, which reports from /proc/stat the number of seconds each CPU spent doing each type of work.

row.entry: Percentage of time that the CPU or CPUs were idle and the system did not have an outstanding disk I/O request. This is the time that the CPU had nothing to do.
Percentage of time that the CPU or CPUs were idle during which the system had an outstanding disk I/O request. This is the time spent waiting for I/O.
Percentage of CPU utilization that occurred while executing at the irq level. This is the time servicing interrupts.
Percentage of CPU utilization that occurred while executing at the nice level. If you are running other VMs, the CPU that they use.
Percentage of CPU utilization that occurred while executing at the softirq level. This is the time servicing interrupts.
Percentage of CPU preempted by the hypervisor. If you are a VM, this is the time other VMs "stole" from your CPUs.
Percentage of CPU utilization that occurred while executing at the system level. this is the time spent in the kernel.
Percentage of CPU utilization that occurred while executing at the user level. this is the time spent in user area.

entry.p: The following are examples in XML format:
entry.codeblock:
<measType p="1">node_cpu.idle</measType> <measType p="2">node_cpu.iowait</measType> <measType p="3">node_cpu.irq</measType> <measType p="4">node_cpu.nice</measType> <measType p="5">node_cpu.softirq</measType> <measType p="6">node_cpu.steal</measType> <measType p="7">node_cpu.system</measType> <measType p="8">node_cpu.user</measType>
<measValue measObjLdn="platform=1, host=ME2-comsvc-2"> <r p="1">45039.94</r> <r p="2">58.56</r> <r p="3">0</r> <r p="4">6</r> <r p="5">109.66</r> <r p="6">3.89</r> <r p="7">661.8</r> <r p="8">1265.48</r> </measValue>

row.entry: The total number of bytes read successfully.
The total number of bytes written successfully.
The number of I/Os currently in progress.
Used for disk utilization. The total milliseconds spent doing disk I/O in one minute.

entry.p: The following are examples in XML format:
entry.codeblock: <measType p="1">node_disk_bytes_read</measType> <measType p="2">node_disk_bytes_written</measType> <measType p="3">node_disk_io_now</measType> <measType p="4">node_disk_io_time_ms</measType> <measValue measObjLdn="platform=1, host=ME2-comsvc-2, device=sr0"> <r p="1">174080</r> <r p="2">0</r> <r p="3">0</r> <r p="4">24</r> </measValue>

<measType p="1">node_filesystem_free</measType> <measType p="2">node_filesystem_size</measType>
<measValue measObjLdn="platform=1, host=ME2-comsvc-2, device=tmpfs, fstype=tmpfs, mountpoint=_var_tmp">
<r p="1">873606656</r> <r p="2">1073741824</r> </measValue>

row.entry: Non-file backed pages mapped into userspace page tables.
Memory in buffer cache, relatively temporary storage for raw disk blocks.
Memory in the pagecache (Diskcache and Shared Memory).
Memory waiting to be written back to disk.
The amount of RAM the kernel identified as corrupted / not working.
Files which have been mapped, such as libraries.
The amount of physical memory not used by the system.
Memory which is actively being written back to disk.

entry.codeblock:
<measType p="1">node_memory_AnonPages</measType> <measType p="2">node_memory_Buffers</measType> <measType p="3">node_memory_Cached</measType> <measType p="4">node_memory_Dirty</measType> <measType p="5">node_memory_HardwareCorrupted</measType> <measType p="6">node_memory_Mapped</measType> <measType p="7">node_memory_MemFree</measType> <measType p="8">node_memory_MemTotal</measType> <measType p="5">node_memory_Shmem</measType> <measType p="6">node_memory_SwapFree</measType> <measType p="7">node_memory_SwapTotal</measType> <measType p="8">node_memory_Writeback</measType>
<measValue measObjLdn="platform=1, host=ME2-comsvc-2"> <r p="1">2506697932.8</r> <r p="2">125219840</r> <r p="3">667828633.6</r> <r p="4">194764.8</r> <r p="5">0</r> <r p="6">73077760</r> <r p="7">4707604070.4</r> <r p="8">8201056256</r> <r p="9">987136</r> <r p="10">4293914624</r> <r p="11">4293914624</r> <r p="12">0</r> </measValue>

section.title: System Java Virtual Machine (JVM) metrics
section.p: NCC collects system metrics related to the Java Virtual Machine (JVM). These may be useful for performing troubleshooting of a system issue. They are recorded in a per-node (e.g. VM) basis. For further reference, see standard internet sources.
The following tables describe the JVM metric attributes collected.

entry.codeblock:
<measType p="1">jvm_info</measType>
<measValue measObjLdn="app=1, jvm=1, host=ME2-comsvc-2, runtime=Java(TM)_SE_Runtime_Environment, vendor==Oracle_Corporation, version=1.8.0_181-b32">

entry.p: Garbage collection detail. Possible values include:

row.entry: Number of live threads currently running.
Number of daemon threads currently running
Number of threads that are in deadlock waiting to acquire object monitors
Number of blocked waiting for a monitor lock.
Number of peak live thread count since the Java virtual machine started or peak was reset.
Total number of threads created and also started since the Java virtual machine started
Used buffer pool (subset of capacity), number of buffers
Used buffer pool (subset of capacity), in bytes

Initial amount of memory pool (in bytes) that the JVM requests from the OS for memory management during startup. The JVM may request additional memory and may also release memory to the system over time. The value may be undefined
Bytes used in the given memory pool

Amount of memory pool (in bytes) that is guaranteed to be available for use by the JVM. The amount of committed memory may change over time (increase or decrease). The JVM may release memory to the system and committed could be less than init. committed will always be greater than or equal to used.

Maximum amount of memory pool (in bytes) that can be used for memory management. Its value may be undefined and may change over time if defined. The amount of used and committed memory will always be less than or equal to max if max is defined. A memory allocation may fail if it attempts to increase the used memory such that used > committed even if used <= max would still be true (for example, when the system is low on virtual memory).

entry.p: JVM memory pool. Possible values include:

row.entry: Initial amount of memory (in bytes) that the JVM requests from the OS for memory management during startup. The JVM may request additional memory and may also release memory to the system over time. The value may be undefined
Amount of memory currently used (in bytes)

Amount of memory (in bytes) that is guaranteed to be available for use by the JVM. The amount of committed memory may change over time (increase or decrease). The JVM may release memory to the system and committed could be less than init. committed will always be greater than or equal to used.

Maximum amount of memory (in bytes) that can be used for memory management. Its value may be undefined and may change over time if defined. The amount of used and committed memory will always be less than or equal to max if max is defined. A memory allocation may fail if it attempts to increase the used memory such that used > committed even if used <= max would still be true (for example, when the system is low on virtual memory).
